9) Does any of this amount to voter suppression? Or “Jim Crow” laws, which explicitly suppressed voters with poll taxes, literacy tests, and grandfather clauses?

Not even close. And BTW, Texas STILL has more opportunities to vote than Joe Biden’s home state. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E6RLuXnWEAMk63q.jpg

8) Ends the temporary, emergency measures that were put in place solely because of the pandemic like drive-thru voting and 24-hour early voting. 

These options never existed before the pandemic, even though Democrats want you to believe we are ending a long-standing practice.

7) Requires those assisting voters with filling out their ballots to complete a form verifying their identity and to take an oath stating that they will not try to influence a voter one way or another.
6) Sets uniform procedures for verifying the authenticity of mail-in ballots while also giving voters the chance to correct mistakes if they are discovered.
5) Strengthens the ban on unmanned mail-in drop boxes and prohibits unsolicited distribution of mail-in ballot applications by public officials.
4) Ensures accountability at the polls by allowing poll watchers to observe election workers, improving transparency and confidence in the results.
3) Sets uniform voting times for early voting to reduce confusion while expanding hours on the weekend. This fixes the different voting times in different counties that confused voters.

And for those on the left who say that these requirements “suppress minority votes,” the data doesn’t back that up.

Voter ID has “no negative effect on registration or turnout, overall or for any group defined by race, gender, age, or party affiliation.” https://www.nber.org/papers/w25522

2) Requires voter ID verification for mail-in ballots in line with in-person voting. Voters can also provide the last 4 digits of their social security number if they don’t have a driver’s license. 80% of Americans support voter ID laws. https://news.gallup.com/poll/194741/four-five-americans-support-voter-laws-early-voting.aspx

1) Bans paid ballot harvesting, the practice of gathering and submitting complete absentee or mail-in voter ballots by third-party individuals, volunteers or party workers, rather than submission by voters themselves directly to ballot collection sites.

What can we do to restore competition to our economy?  

@POTUS’ recent EO on Promoting Competition in the American Economy was a critical first step – it will help foster innovation and ensure that a larger share of corporate profits go to workers. https://mobile.twitter.com/WhiteHouseCEA/status/1413486082189103105 QT @WhiteHouseCEA In a blogpost, CEA analyzes the United States' trends toward market concentration, the negative consequences of greater concentration, and the need for robust policy change as a result. 1/ https://www.whitehouse.gov/cea/blog/2021/07/09/the-importance-of-competition-for-the-american-economy/

The share of corporate-sector income received by workers reflects a similar long-run decline:  
 
The rise in corporate market power and the erosion of competition has deprived US workers of $1.5 trillion in income.

Workers are losing out. Over the past 15 years, the labor share of income has decreased in the U.S. 

By contrast, it has remained relatively constant in Europe. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E6RH2KoWUAggPF5.png

A range of measures point to decreased business dynamism. We can observe a significant decline in the number of publicly listed firms and a major increase in the number of merger and acquisition deals.  

Large companies are essentially swallowing small businesses. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E6RHrxfXsAMpxPe.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E6RHwLjWUAIz4S2.png

While corporate profits are at record highs, re-investment in capital has declined—firms today invest less per dollar of profits today than they did 20 years ago, and industries with larger increases in concentration no longer reflect larger productivity gains. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E6RHeTFXoAklAHN.png
The profit share has increased to 9%, and firms in concentrated industries are more likely to experience rising profit margins than their counterparts in less-concentrated industries.

For 50 years, the ratio of profits to GDP remained relatively stable at about 7%. But for the last 2 decades, corporate profits have outpaced GDP growth. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E6RHYIUXMAA4ueS.png

In today’s hearing at 2:30pm ET, we’re examining the causes & consequences of increasing corporate concentration and #CorporatePower.

Our economy is less competitive today than it was decades ago—and it’s harming our consumers, workers, and small businesses.

.@RepDonBeyer: “@POTUS’ Executive Order advances a whole-of-government approach to promote fair competition, and it is now our turn to act here in Congress with bold and decisive action.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “We have an opportunity now to restore a competitive economy and advance shared prosperity.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “Earlier this year, the @SenAmyKlobuchar introduced the Competition and Antitrust Law Enforcement Reform Act. Among other things, this bill would give federal enforcers more resources to do their jobs and strengthen prohibitions on anticompetitive conduct.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “In the Senate, my dear friend and colleague, @SenAmyKlobuchar wrote an entire book about antitrust, the challenges we face and what we can do to make our economy more competitive.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “Following a bipartisan investigation that uncovered evidence of ample anti-competitive practices, the @HouseJudiciary recently approved six bipartisan bills to address business concentration and bolster competition on digital platforms.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “Additionally, there have been productive bipartisan conversations here on Capitol Hill about how to best tack these challenges.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “The good news is that there are steps that we as a country can take to reduce this concentration of corporate power. We’ll hear more about these proposals from our expert panel today.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “During this time, our economy has lost half of its firms on a per capita basis. This has disproportionately impacted marginalized communities, where we’ve seen a disappearance of independent grocery stores, pharmacies and community banks.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “This is due in part to our failed experiment with a more lax enforcement of antitrust laws and the under-funding of federal enforcement agencies.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “The explosion of mergers & acquisitions have a played a key role in the consolidation of industries. Over the past 40 years, they've been allowed to proceed at an unprecedented pace, & the same holds for an array of anticompetitive practices by industry leaders.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “Our workers are also paying for this in the form of stagnant wages. Research shows, the median American household loses an estimated $5,000 each year through reduced wages and higher prices caused by a lack of competition.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “This is a problem because consumers are bearing the burden. On average, we pay about twice as much for cellphone plans than some of our friends in other advanced economies with more providers. The same is true for broadband access.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “Amid record-breaking profits, corporations are paying less in taxes today than they did 30 years ago while reinvesting 10 cents less per dollar of profit. All of this has led to reduced productivity gains in concentrated industries and slower growth economy-wide.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “This consolidation of corporate power has allowed the wealthiest at the top to capture a larger share of the gains from economic growth…”
.@RepDonBeyer: “Evidence shows this has led to weaker business investment, higher prices for consumers and lower wages for workers.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “Across industries—including health care, financial services, telecommunications, agriculture and more—we are seeing higher levels of concentration than there were three decades ago.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “We are here today because corporate concentration imperils shared prosperity and exacerbates economic inequality.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “Research shows the possibility of new entrants into a market compels existing firms to continue investing in people and capital to stay ahead, which also elevates the United States as a leader in the global economy”

.@RepDonBeyer: “Competition for workers incentivizes firms to pay good wages or risk losing their workers to competitors, thereby serving as a counterbalance to rising corporate power and enabling workers to bargain for better working conditions.”

.@RepDonBeyer: “Competition in markets leads to lower prices and higher quality goods and services, ensuring that consumers do not overpay for the products and services they rely on, whether a vital medication or broadband internet.”
.@RepDonBeyer: “Access to opportunity, open markets and fair competition are fundamental to advancing shared prosperity in our country.”
